description.text: In this image, Bharat Mata or Mother India is seen holding a tricolour flag fixed on a trident and standing on the map of India. She is wearing a crown and her hands are tied in chains. In the background, Bal Gangadhar Tilak and three other Indian freedom fighters can be seen.

location.name: Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art
Delhi / The Priya Paul Collection of Popular Art

rights.text: Copyrighted. Copyright with the original artists and publishers.

ext:item.ext:value: description-en: In this image, Bharat Mata or Mother India is seen holding a tricolour flag fixed on a trident and standing on the map of India. She is wearing a crown and her hands are tied in chains. In the background, Bal Gangadhar Tilak and three other Indian freedom fighters can be seen. (gs/sp)

explanatory comments/crosstagging: The map of India is necessary of course because its presence in her visual persona allows Mother India to be distinguished from the numerous other Hindu goddesses whose calendar art incarnations she otherwise resembles. At the same time, prints like Hind-Mata appear to suggest that it is the mother’s body more than the geo-body of the nation that is important for citizen-viewers to focus upon as they reflect upon this composite image of India as a “carto-graphed” mother/goddess. In the process, borders and boundaries—the very sine qua non of normative state cartography—are transformed to accommodate the mother’s body, in some cases even completely disappearing to allow for the free flow or her saree, her hair or her limbs. (Sumathi Ramaswamy)(gs)
related literature: Coplan, Ian, 1997. The Princes of India in the Endgame of Empire, 1917-1947. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, pp. 229-287. (gs)
related literature: Guha, Ramachandra, 2008. India after Gandhi (New York: HarperCollins), pp. 51-96. (gs)

The map of India is necessary of course because its presence in her visual persona allows Mother India to be distinguished from the numerous other Hindu goddesses whose calendar art incarnations she otherwise resembles. At the same time, prints like Hind-Mata appear to suggest that it is the mother’s body more than the geo-body of the nation that is important for citizen-viewers to focus upon as they reflect upon this composite image of India as a “carto-graphed” mother/goddess. In the process, borders and boundaries—the very sine qua non of normative state cartography—are transformed to accommodate the mother’s body, in some cases even completely disappearing to allow for the free flow or her saree, her hair or her limbs.
